reviewText:
Upon completing the Longest Journey, I wasn't surprised it constantly gets ranked in top PC game lists.

Clocking in at a solid 25 hours, it will keep you entertained for quite a while. You do have to put yourself into the Click and Point Adventure mindset however, as it is by no means, a fast paced game. It's more like an interactive book.

The game for me shined the most in its dialogue. Nearly every character has an incredibly natural enunciation rarely found in games. It gives you a stronger connection with them, and helps you believe every word.

The next best parts of the Longest Journey was its story and variety of characters. It takes place in the 23rd century Venice, and gives a fascinating perspective of the past, present, and future. With a story as interesting as this, that's all I can really say without spoiling anything.
The characters feature a wide range of tallent and personallity, which makes them so interesting to talk to. By the first sentence someone utters, you already know what kind of person he/she is, and how he/she is going to treat you, it really is that detailed.

For a game stuck in 640x480 resolution, it is full of very detailed and beautiful scenery. 3D objects are pretty pixelated and jaggy, and are probably the thing that aged the worst. Some up-resing would benefit The Longest Journey pretty well, but I quickly became lost in everything else it had to offer, that the quality rarely bothered me.

The puzzles as well can be pretty cryptic. I had to look up a guild many times to figure out what to do next. That didn't bother me too much either, but it would have been nice if the main character gave hits on what to do.

I am currently working through the sequel, Dreamfall, which early on already has reoccuring characters and locations, and because it came out 6 years after the first, it's nice to see things in better detail.

If you want a less action oriented experience that feels like a mix of an interactive painting and a best selling novel, I highly recommend picking up the double pack. With a promising 3rd installment in the works, how can you go wrong?

reviewText: The Longest Journey does its name justice. It is an epic adventure from beginning to end and it never gets tedious or boring like a lot of adventure games tend to do when they try to forcefully increase the playtime. The setting is unique, intriguing and creates a great atmosphere. The plot is original and inspiring and shows what adventure games can do when they're done right. The brightest aspect of the game, however are the characters. From the heroine to the minor characters, they are all wonderfully designed with a certain integrity that makes them incredibly powerful. They bring the story to life and make for a truly memorable game. This could not have been done without the excellent writing and voice acting. The only argument I have against the game's excellence is the pacing and execution of the lest stretch before the finale, which compared to the rest of the game seemed rushed. It seems as if the development team was not able to give this segment the attention and devotion that it deserved. It is a small issue barely worth mentioning however, since the rest of the game shines brightly.\n\nIf adventure games are your thing, this is a must-play.

reviewText:
English review (Polska wersja, jak zawsze, niżej):

By completing the Steam version of The Longest Journey I have broken one of the most basic principles of gaming: One does not simply come back to playing a game that one loved more than ten years ago. But upon doing so I have to tell you two things: This game aged pretty badly. And it hasn’t got old one bit. These two sentences do not constitute a paradox.

Back in the days, the art of TLJ was simply breathtaking, which nowadays clearly isn’t the case. The 2d backgrounds are still impressive, but all the models are old and ugly. If you’re going to play this game in modern times take my advice and override the display settings from your graphic card’s control panel. TLJ really benefits from trilinear filtering.

Having said that, besides the models and somewhat clunky and dated controls ( though nothing really serious) TLJ remains the most complete adventure game experience I have ever played. The game skilfully balances between the hard dystopian sci-fi and magical fantasy, creating a truly uniqe and extensive storyline, the characters –even these appearing for a few minutes – are charming and original, and the humor is clever and entertaining. Speaking of characters: the game’s protagonist – April Ryan – is perhaps the most developed and unique character in gaming. And also, it should be noted that the game soon turns much more adult and dark than one should expect from a story about girl jumping back and forth between the worlds of magic and reason ( but then it swings back to cheerful fairytale just to get even more serious in the next chapters).

The voice acting is stunning. Actors do an unforgettable job, especially during the final chapters of the game. This may come up as a surprise since if you pay attention to credits, you will notice that one actor often voices three or four characters.  Furthermore, the dialogues are written in a truly brilliant way – even the shortest ones are witty and memorable.

While it can be argued that after finishing there is nothing much to come back to (there is The Book of Secrets but obviously I won’t tell you what’s inside…), a single playthrough took me 16 hours which is enough time for two point and click games. While the puzzles usually aren’t that difficult (usually… the rubber ducky puzzle)and don’t take that much time,still there is an INCREDIBLE amount of lore, and some dialogues can take few minutes while characters convey that information. Vestrum Tobias is particularly guilty of that, since he introduces April to the story of the world. Worlds.

The ending is perhaps the most fulfilled and satisfactory conclusion to a game I have ever seen, but it leaves a sense of melancholy. I will probably play this game in the next ten years just the way I tend to re-read certain books to measure them against the impact of years. This may be the only game in my entire Steam library that I would grade ten out of ten without hesitation. And in the meantime, I’ ll be waiting for The Longest Journey Home…

reviewText:
Best point and click adventure game I’ve ever played. Up there, if not more enjoyable than The Curse of Monkey Island, Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars and The Walking Dead - I can see now why it is scored so highly.

First of all The Longest Journey no doubt requires a lot of patience. The game shares more familiarities with a novel, having an extraordinary amount of dialogue to go through and numerous objects to click on and explore. Story felt refreshingly unique and flows well. It is split into thirteen Chapters of varying length and themes. The voice acting is brilliant – characters feel natural, not samey and often time’s humorous (mature content).

Puzzles on reflection were mostly straight forward, logical and challenging – and only had to use a guide for small sections of the game that didn’t make sense or where I forgot one piece of dialogue (you need to complete certain things in order to continue with the plot). Graphics and cut scenes look dated at first impression but soon becomes part of the games charm. Musical soundtrack does a fantastic job at conveying the different moods throughout the journey.

Chapter Three is the funniest, and cements the fact that this is now one of my favourite point and click games. Definitely a masterpiece.

10/10

reviewText:
I had no idea what to expect from this game - I had heard that this series by Funcom/Red Thread was quite good, but I wasn't prepared for the Journey that lay in store. (har har)

To be completely fair, the graphics are, as expected, very dated. But as an avid fan of the old point 'n' clicks, that came as no surprise to me. That being said, the static backgrounds were often very good and at times even striking. Gave me that warm nostalgic feeling without ever causing any real troubles with seeing items or what is going on.

Probably the highest compliment I can give to such a game is to say that I almost never came out of a puzzle still feeling frustrated. For illustration, let me compare this title to some of the old Sierra games (which I adore): frequently in Sierra games, you would either spend hours banging your head against the wall or break down and look up a hint to get you through some tough puzzles only to find that you needed to:
pound the wall next door to
knock a painting off the wall which
fell on a rat to stun him then
pick up the rat and
choose the correct dialog choices to make him bite you
wipe your bleeding hand on your napkin in order to
finally get the red pocket square you've been needing.Yes, this kind of makes sense. But no level of thought would have ever led you to that conclusion on your own. So usually, you are left to wander around trying every verb on every noun in the blasted game until the solution just falls into your lap. Not a very rewarding feeling.

On the other hand, TLJ only incited that feeling once or twice. True, some of the puzzles were especially easy -- perhaps too easy -- but I went through the story feeling smart and engaged.

The last compliment I can give this game applies to the series (and studio) in general, but also applies here. Funcom/Red Thread are great at making their games inclusive (e.g. female protagonist, racial diversity, different sexualities) which really adds to the immersion for me. Being in a world that more accurately reflects the real world creates depth and allows me to get swept up on a journey of my own.

This is now one of my all-time favorite point-and-clicks and games and series. 5/5

reviewText:
Adventure games are not for everyone.  They have little replay value unless you enjoy the story so much that after the first playthrough you want to experience it again.

What's interesting about The Longest Journey is that it appeared during a time when adventure games had largely fallen out of favor.  The odds of it becoming a success were slim.

However, writer Ragnar Tørnquist knows how to assemble a compelling, quirky and funny story that captures the hearts and minds of many gamers.  For this reason, TLJ has become one of the best adventure games of all time.

Female characters in video games don't always have complexity, but April Ryan is one of the most interesting characters I have ever encountered.  It is a joy to observe her grow as a person as I play, from a woman unsure of her future and place in the world to a savior of the people.

Also, I love how Tørnquist successfully blends both cyberpunk and fantasy elements together to create a unique narrative.

I don't recall encountering a nonsensical puzzle, either, which is a flaw that some adventure games have.

Update:  It's still a wonderful game and I played through it again because I've been going through a TLJ binge, but I had some trouble getting the game to display correctly even though it had worked for me in the past.  You may need to run this in compatibility mode to get it to work.

reviewText:
There has been a time, around 2000, everybody was thinking  that maybe graphic adventures were doomed. After the commercial failure of Grim Fandango the future seemed obscure, and The Longest Journey was a shining light. Maybe I am too melodramatic, but I like to think that TLJ saved this genre, because it showed to everyone that it was still possible to make extraordinary point and click games.

I won't tell you anything about the story, if not that it has a strong sci-fi/paranormal vibe, because I really want you to discover it entirely. The setting is futuristic, and you'll help the main character, April Ryan, discover the truth about herself and the world she lives in. The characters are deep and very well written, the story manages to be funny and allegoric at the same time, and the puzzles can be really challenging. Old School. Awesome. reviewText:
Epic novel

Playing 'The Longest Journey' felt like reading a captivating story, rather than playing a game. Sure, there are plenty of puzzles to solve, but it's the story that will have you hooked. You play as April Ryan, an artist who moved to Venice from the countryside,  who is struggling to make ends meet in her art career. Everything changes when she meets a man named Cortez, where she gets herself into a plot to save both worlds of order (science) and chaos (magic).

Gameplay is presented in the usual 'point and click' fashion. You click on areas of the map to move April, double clicking will make her run. You can press 'escape' to skip animations (if you allowed this in the options menu) and dialogue if you just want to progress through the story quickly (although I recommend not to skip the dialogue as you may miss important information). You can interact with characters and objects by simply clicking on them. There is an inventory system which allows you to store and use items to solve the puzzles. The puzzles  may be a bit tricky to solve as your not given a clear indication of where to go and how to solve the puzzles, which makes you refer to the 'trial and error' approach. Other times you will be moving back and forth areas due to some fetch quests. The store page says the game will last you '40 + hours' although I completed it in about 17 hours through using a wlakthrough (because I wanted to progress the story, without dealing with the puzzles).

The graphics are somewhat outdated in this current age. 3D-models are a bit blocky and the textures aren't as detailed as other games in the genre. Having said that, they do a decent job at setting the atmosphere in the various environments you roam in. The CG movies haven't aged well either.

Plot is where this game trully shines. The story is unique and will keep you guessing as it unravels. Voice acting of the main characters (especially April herself) is excellent and believeable, minor characters voice acting are somewhat mediocre. Your emotions will be tested here as you will feel a sense of wonder and awe, fear, laughs and a bit of sadness as the you progress though the story. The music is also decent at setting the mood.

Furthermore, you can unlock 'The book of secrets' which contains dialogue and music which were removed from the final product.

I highly recommend this game to point-and click gamers looking for a good story and don't mind solving puzzles (although I do advise using a walkthrough).

One of the greatest adventure games ever to be made. The visuals look very dated and the game only runs in 640x480. Even when it first came out this game wasn't anywhere near the prettiest around. Having said that the 2D backgrounds are stylish in their own way and do a good job of setting the mood for each particular scene.

If you can look past the graphical shortcomings and take it for what it is, the writing, the characters and the world will blow you away. All characters are fully voiced and the acting mostly lives up to a high standard. The semi-orchestral soundtrack is also amazing and boasts some very memorable themes.

The puzzles are mostly standard point-and-click-fare. There are a few particularly obnoxious spots where the solutions can only be found by randomly combining things without any clear logic behind it (yes, duck clamp rope, I'm referring to you). All in all, much like the graphics, the puzzles are something of a weak link but still solid enough to not detract from the overall experience.

The story is the main attraction here. Combining scifi and fantasy the plot reaches some epic heights. It might start a little slow, but in my opinion it only makes it feel even more grand when it eventually starts picking up momentum. The story goes into some pretty dark places, and you might be in for a more mature experience than you may first think. When it came out and I first played it, I'd never heard so much swearing in a video game. Of course the industry has changed a lot during the years, and that aspect will probably not be as much of a shocker as it was then.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes a good story, especially if they're into scifi or fantasy. Those more gameplay oriented might just want to give this one a pass, since the puzzles really are just a vessel for delivering the main attraction.

The Longest Journey by Funcom takes us on April Ryan's adventure to save the world(s)! I didn't know what to expect from this game, especially since I'm not a huge fan of point-and-click adventure games, but The Longest Journey is easily the best p-a-c game I've ever played, and is a highly worthwhile title for its story alone. The backgrounds are beautifully done, but the character models are quite dated; that said, that doesn't really matter, because the writing, world-building, and characterization are incredibly manufactured and suck you so deeply into this adventure you soon don't care about looking at a blocky April texture. Seriously, there are more memorable characters in this game than the last several games I've played *combined*. Crow, The Wheel Man, The Flipster, and especially April - she's an incredibly *real* character. I'm just flabbergasted how well Funcom has pulled her off. She seems just like an 18 year old girl would, and the rest (or most important) of the characters are equally deep and interesting. To add to this characterization, the voice acting is also outstanding (mostly, there were a few poor ones) and...I just really can't get over how real April was, I honestly feel like I know her, and the rest of the characters too - they're very dynamic and just so well done. There are also lots of dialogue choices to pick through that don't pertain to *immediate* story progression used to flesh out the worlds and the characters - this was much appreciated, and made the created universe feel large and dynamic. There were other nice features as well: the setting was very unique, there was a video replay option to view the FMVs, nicely done music...However, the downfall of any point and click adventure game are the puzzles. Some are very convoluted. I remember one where you had to make a fishing pole out of some kind of string, an inflateable duck, and a bandaide. It was just too much for me, I admit, I used a walkthrough. That said, I would recommend using a walkthrough if you get stuck in this game - it's definitely worth playing, even for a p-a-c adventure game.

reviewText: For me this is one of those games that it's almost impossible to take an objective perspective on just because it made such a profound impact on me at a young age. Could it be one of the best adventure games ever made? Most definitely. Maybe even in the top 5. If I had to put on my objective hat and evaluate it I would be forced to admit that it does have some wonky puzzles at times (particularly in the first chapter) and a few instances of somewhat awkward massive exposition dump (particularly the first time you get to Arcadia), but the world it creates, its characters, and more importantly, the way it introduces you to and draws you into that world puts this game in a class all its own--not only among adventure games, but video games in general.\n\nAnyhow, regardless of its position in the history of gaming as a whole, I do think it's safe to say that there's probably no better adventure game on steam than this. So if you've yet to play it do so now.

reviewText:
You're going to look at my hour record and think that I've never played this game. Don't let that fool you. I've been playing this game for years and I know it back to front and inside out.
You play as a young woman called April Ryan who is trying to find her way in the world, as an artist. Instead, she crosses to another world, back and forth, saving the worlds time and time again with her faithful feathered side-kick, Crow.
She fights big corporations, shady underground factions and meets a collection of interesting people and races along the way, who both help and hinder her.
If you're thinking about getting this game, do it. I beg you. You won't be disappointed.
The longest journey will forever be at the top of my favourite games of all time.
The characters are not only memorable but relatable... and oh so lovable. I can't stop singing the praises of this game.
May the balance protect you.

reviewText:
There are a lot of stale fantasy games out there. Games about men with swords and false British accents fighting monsters and animals alongside Dwarves and Elves. Few are the games which can truly create a unique world full of unique creatures and characters, and a unique story to go along with it. The Longest Journey is proof that, if nothing else, those sword & Elf games are just being lazy.

The Longest Journey is a good title, I feel. There's plenty lot of plot, and it's pretty important. Seeing the plot through to its conclusion is also important. But in this game, I wouldn't hesistate for a moment to say that the journey is far more important than the destination. For all the characters, I can't think of one that I didn't like - hero, villain, or neutral. From an egotistical wizard, to a short-tempered and superstitious captain, to the duly unloved police force, to your ladies' bird sidekick, to Burns Flipper, they're all memorable in their own way. And all of the races you'll meet along the way - the complexly-named ones who sing to the soil, the tense-confused ones who experience their entire lives simultaneously and the flying ones who hold storytelling in one's own words to be integral to their culture, to name only a few - are so fascinating that for all the time spent learning about each of them, I'm a little bummed out that I couldn't learn more.

The places you go are as wonderful as they are mysterious, and are only made moreso by the clash between the two worlds - the technological world of Stark, and the magical world of Arcadia. When I first visited the Haven Age of Myst IV: Revelation, I was greeted with stormy skies, a rough ocean, and an upturned shipwreck, all looming ahead. Once I climbed the nearby rock and peered over the other side, I saw bright skies, and a colorful, inviting jungle. The sheer wonder of this clash stopped me solid in my tracks, leaving me to admire the sharply contrasting views for some time before finally moving on.

This is what The Longest Journey is like *all the time*. Just on a much larger scale.

The journey is indeed long, for an adventure game. It's not always entirely forgiving; there are one or two infamous moon logic-y puzzles that are sure to frustrate, but please don't let them dissuade you. Barring those moments, The Longest Journey is such a lovingly crafted adventure, full of twists and turns, technology and magic, characters and exploration, and Burns Flipper, and it's all held together by April Ryan, our caring but sarcastic protagonist. April Ryan is, in my own opinion, the best-written female character of any video game I've ever played. And it's a good thing too, given the sheer amount of dialogue she has, all vocalized perfectly by Sarah Hamilton.

I play a lot of adventure games. The Longest Journey is without a doubt one of the best I have ever played, and I cannot recommend it enough. It's creative, it's well-written, it's mostly well-voiced, the majority of the puzzles make sense, and April only looks terrifying in the FMVs. Don't be on the fence about this one. Get it.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This was one of my childhood favorites, and although I've replayed it a couple of times in recent years the nostalgia goggles are so tight they've become a part of my skull and cannot be removed. Tablespoons of salt required as condiment to this review.

TLJ is a slow-paced point-and-click RPG with a unique world concept and layered, realistic characters. The story is the primary draw, as it is both well written and executed with complimenting dialogue. You're put in the shoes of an accidental heroine with a personality to match her background as a struggling artist in a cyberpunk-age Venice. She, and many other characters in this game may not be immediately likeable, but are given genuine character devlopment throughout. Well-written characters, the lore and depth of the world are the crowning jewels of this game. It is rare to find such a profound world concept outside a game based on a traditional tabletop RPG system. While the physical exploration of the world is limited to relatively small, contained maps at a time, exploration is achieved hand-in-hand with the storytelling and puzzle-solving and not as an elaborate sidequest. Many secrets and hidden and revealed in dialogue and visuals, and there is more to the world than what April herself sees. You may want to take notes.

In terms of Roleplaying, you cannot change April's character. You're not entirely playing the game as her, either. The player is like a ghost looking over her shoulder, she will talk to herself more like she's talking to you, but never remark upon your presence.

To address the gameplay, this is stricthly a point-and-click adventure. You will not be engaged in active combat, you will need to find ways to circumvent conflict and bridge gaps in the road. The puzzles can at times be archaic and occasionally absurd, but if you're patient and put occam's razor to good use you will find your way. If you fail to do this, or simply cannot handle puzzle-solving games, following a guide and playing this game just for the story is still worth it.

The game's length is about 25-30 hours if you don't spend a lot of time solving the puzzles. This is enough time to unfold an epic cyberpunk/fantasy-hybrid tale in the pace that it deserves. This is a game where you do not start in medias res, and the ending is not rushed; everything happens in due time.

I would recommend this game to lovers of good stories. I do not have enough experience with puzzle-games to remark upon the quality of TLJ as such, but I can say as a well-versed RPG player and bookworm that this is story worth experiencing. TLJ sets its' own expectations and fulfills them. [10/10]

reviewText:
This game is one of the greatest point & click adventure games I have played so far. If you took my top games of all time, it would be on it. Maybe not number one, what with all of these truly amazing games you see, but it would be there and not too low.

The Graphics are a bit dated, but not an issue.
The music was a bit forgettable but good, and quite fitting.
The story is great, I really did like it quite a lot. Throughout the whole game it was intriguing and fun to experience.
The Puzzles were at times quite challenging, but rewarding, and isn't that what you want from a puzzle game?

reviewText: Having never played this game's sequel, I thought it would be novel (and necessary, due to having forgotten most of the details of the complex story) to replay TLJ before taking on Dreamfall for the first time. So the big question is: how does this game (which I considered to be an adventure masterpiece a decade ago) hold up today? The verdict is mixed. On one hand, it nearly perfects the classic adventure formula (click stuff, talk to people, solve puzzles), the number of absurd puzzle solutions are minimal, and the story is well thought out. But on the other hand, the writing, while well-intended, sometimes comes off as amateurish. The script is also extremely verbose and really could have used some serious editing. The graphics, of course, are extremely dated, but that is easily forgiven. All in all, the spirit of the game holds up well, if not the technical side. Assuming you are a fan of the genre and can overlook its dated flaws, it is still fun to play today. A true classic!

reviewText:
While this game was likely amazing in its time, I could only recommend it if you still have a love for adventure games of that era and their tropes.

Pros
-Great story
- Unique setting
- Likeable protagonist
- Diverse cast of characters
- Despite their age, the graphics are pretty decent

Cons
- Lots of running through nice-looking but otherwise featureless screens
- Puzzles only make sense in retrospect
- It's often not obvious what is interactive in a scene. Quite a bit of pixel hunting.

Overall, this game only holds up well when bolstered by nostalgia. Otherwise, while it may have been stellar in its time, it still suffers from many of the frustrating gameplay tropes that adventure games have left behind.

reviewText:
I can see that this game took an incredible amount of work and I'm sure many of the games themes will appeal to a certain audience but I just couldn't get into it.

Apparently this game is one of the longest point and click adventure games of all time. Trust me, I believe it.

I like to consider myself a patient person but this game has way too much dialogue for its own good. It's hard for me to stay engaged when conversations go on forever and most of the dialogue is fluff. I'm sure I'd give this game another shot if they just trimmed the fat and focused on more of the core themes of the story.

They tried far too hard to make April a normal everyday girl and maybe they have succeeded to an extent. But she doesn't come off as relatable, or heroic, or even interesting, she's just all around bland... and whinny. So, damn, whinny. This wouldn't be so bad if the side characters were interesting. There are a few here and there that are, but not enough to slog through the entire game.

I'm sure there are people who would enjoy this game for what it is but I expect my games to engage me on some level, whether conceptually, emotionally, or through raw stimulation. I was patient and kind to this game and was left feeling as if it wasn't worth my time.

Not recommended unless you are a die-hard adventure fan.

The Longest Journey is a phenomenal story in a decent game. The world building is amazing, the settings are gorgeous, the voice acting is Hollywood quality, and the story itself is one of the best I've ever seen. If you're like me, and drawn more towards the story in a game than the actual gameplay, buy this immediately. The game is visually stunning, even when you take into account the late-90's CGI characters. Their animations are a bit slow and clunky, but to me, the beautifully rendered 2-D backgrounds more than compensated. And the characters themselves were so well thought out and well-rounded, with stories and lives beyond the game, combined with top notch voice acting, that it makes me care a lot less about what they looked like.

That being said, I felt the gameplay was a little flat. Some of the puzzles were pretty obscure, and there was a lack of in-game hints (there were times I had absolutely no idea even what puzzle I was meant to solve; I think they really missed the opportunity to make April's diary more helpful in that respect). And, like most point-and-click games, there is no danger if you get things wrong-- the game just won't progress until you do them correctly-- and replay value is, unfortunately, nil. It dragged in a few places, either from the clunky character animations, or just too much dialogue, and I often felt more like a passive watcher of events than the main character out to save the world.

Storywise, there's not many games out there that can compare to The Longest Journey, and in the end, the story is one of the most important aspects of a game to me. As it is, I'd rate this an 8.5/10. I think if it had just been a little more interactive, or maybe had some alternate endings, it would have been the perfect game for me, late-90's CGI and all.

The Longest Journey is a point-and-click adventure game that takes place in the parallel universes of Arcadia, a world of magic, and Stark, a world science and technology.

The protagonist, April Ryan, is an 18-year-old art student living in Stark. She learns that the line between the two worlds is growing thin, causing chaos on both sides. April also learns that she is a Shifter, one who is capable of walking between these worlds, and is then tasked with restoring the Balance between the dimensions before it is too late.

Definitely one of the best point & click adventures I've ever played.

The puzzles are mostly really easy to figure out. There are only a few harder but still managable ones. If I still got stuck - which happened quite often - I just took a look into a walkthrough. But that wasn't because I couldn't solve a riddle, sometimes the game just doesn't give you any hint at all on what's your next (illogical) step, there are some easily missable items and sometimes you have to trigger an event by looking at some insignificant thing in the environment.

However, the greatest thing about this game is its story. It's exciting, you always feel that you're getting forward and you find a lot of lore throughout the game.
So basically there are two worlds: The logical world Stark, which is basically a dystopian future of our own, and the magical Arcadia, which is some kind of a dream world. (Notice the Lovecraft reference? It's not the only one)
The game keeps putting you in both of them, whereever you are it feels entirely different but it still manages to make sense.

The Longest Journey is a phenomenal story in a decent game. The world building is amazing, the settings are gorgeous, the voice acting is Hollywood quality, and the story itself is one of the best I've ever seen. If you're like me, and drawn more towards the story in a game than the actual gameplay, buy this immediately. The game is visually stunning, even when you take into account the late-90's CGI characters. Their animations are a bit slow and clunky, but to me, the beautifully rendered 2-D backgrounds more than compensated. And the characters themselves were so well thought out and well-rounded, with stories and lives beyond the game, combined with top notch voice acting, that it makes me care a lot less about what they looked like.

That being said, I felt the gameplay was a little flat. Some of the puzzles were pretty obscure, and there was a lack of in-game hints (there were times I had absolutely no idea even what puzzle I was meant to solve; I think they really missed the opportunity to make April's diary more helpful in that respect). And, like most point-and-click games, there is no danger if you get things wrong-- the game just won't progress until you do them correctly-- and replay value is, unfortunately, nil. It dragged in a few places, either from the clunky character animations, or just too much dialogue, and I often felt more like a passive watcher of events than the main character out to save the world.

Storywise, there's not many games out there that can compare to The Longest Journey, and in the end, the story is one of the most important aspects of a game to me. As it is, I'd rate this an 8.5/10. I think if it had just been a little more interactive, or maybe had some alternate endings, it would have been the perfect game for me, late-90's CGI and all.
